questions.stem: What is the most important factor when deciding how to write a document?

options.label: The writer's expertise and knowledge
The readers' needs, knowledge level, and goals
The organization's preferred style
The length requirements of the document

questions.rationale: Everything you write should be designed around your readers' needs, knowledge level, and goals. Know your audience first.

questions.stem: Which sentence is better written for a general audience?

options.label: Implement multi-factor authentication protocols to enhance security posture
Use two-step login to keep your account safe
Deploy MFA solutions to mitigate unauthorized access vectors
Activate enhanced authentication mechanisms

questions.rationale: The second option uses plain language that general readers can understand: 'two-step login' instead of technical jargon.

questions.stem: Match each audience type with the appropriate writing approach:

pairs.right: Use precise technical terms they'll understand
Define technical terms or use simpler alternatives
Lead with key points and conclusions

questions.rationale: Different audiences need different approaches. Always match your writing style to your readers' knowledge and needs.

questions.stem: Complete this reader-focused question: 'Will my readers _______ this term?'
questions.rationale: A key reader-focused question is whether your readers will understand the terms you're using.

questions.stem: When writing for readers under time pressure, you should:

options.label: Include all possible details so they have complete information
Use technical language to be more precise
Put the most important information first and make it easy to scan
Write longer sentences to provide more context

questions.rationale: Readers under pressure need key information quickly and clearly. Put important information first and make it scannable.

questions.stem: What should appear first in a well-organized document?

options.label: Background information and context
A purpose statement telling readers what to expect
Detailed procedures and instructions
Supporting evidence and research

questions.rationale: Start with a purpose statement that tells readers immediately why the document exists and what they'll learn.

questions.stem: Arrange these organizational strategies from most to least appropriate for writing step-by-step instructions:
questions.rationale: For step-by-step instructions, chronological order is most logical, followed by order of importance for key steps.

questions.stem: Which organizational pattern works best for addressing common concerns?

options.label: Chronological
General to specific
Question and answer
Problem to solution

questions.rationale: Question and answer format directly addresses readers' concerns and is easy to scan for specific information.

questions.stem: Put the most _______ information where readers will see it first.
questions.rationale: The most important information should be positioned where readers will see it first - at the beginning.

questions.stem: What should headings do in a well-organized document?

options.label: Show off the writer's creativity
Clearly indicate what content follows
Use complex vocabulary to seem professional
Be as short as possible regardless of clarity

questions.rationale: Headings should clearly indicate content so readers can find what they need quickly and understand the document's structure.

questions.stem: Which word choice follows plain language principles?

options.label: Facilitate → Help
Help → Facilitate
Simple → Uncomplicated
Use → Utilize

questions.rationale: 'Help' is more familiar and concrete than 'facilitate.' Choose words that readers know and use.

questions.stem: Match the complex word with its plain language alternative:
questions.rationale: These plain language alternatives are shorter, more familiar, and more natural-sounding.

questions.stem: When should you use technical jargon in government writing?

options.label: Always, to sound professional
Never, it's always inappropriate
Only when you're sure readers understand it
Only in very long documents

questions.rationale: Use technical jargon only when you're certain your readers understand it. When in doubt, use plain language or define terms.

questions.stem: Click on the word that should be simplified in this sentence:
questions.text: We will endeavour to facilitate your request in an expeditious manner.
questions.rationale: 'Endeavour' should be 'try' - it's simpler and more direct. The whole sentence could be: 'We will try to help you quickly.'

questions.stem: Why should you use consistent terminology throughout a document?

options.label: To show your vocabulary range
To avoid boring readers with repetition
To prevent reader confusion and maintain clarity
To meet word count requirements

questions.rationale: Consistent terminology prevents confusion. Don't vary words for the same concept - it makes readers wonder if you mean something different.

questions.stem: What is the recommended average sentence length for plain language?

options.label: 10-12 words
15-20 words
25-30 words
35+ words

questions.rationale: Average 15-20 words per sentence. This length is easier to follow while still allowing for complete thoughts.

questions.stem: Which sentence uses active voice correctly?

options.label: Mistakes were made in processing applications
Applications were processed incorrectly
We made mistakes when processing applications
Errors were found in the application process

questions.rationale: Active voice is more direct: 'We made mistakes' clearly identifies who did what, unlike passive voice constructions.

questions.stem: Break up long sentences to express _____ main idea per sentence.
questions.rationale: Each sentence should express one main idea. This makes writing clearer and easier to follow.

questions.stem: Which revision eliminates unnecessary words?

options.label: Past experience → Previous experience
End result → Final result
Free gift → Gift
Future plans → Upcoming plans

questions.rationale: 'Free gift' is redundant because gifts are by definition free. 'Gift' alone is sufficient.

questions.stem: How should you handle complex policy information in plain language?

options.label: Keep all information in one comprehensive sentence
Break it into shorter sentences with one idea each
Use more technical terms to be precise
Write longer paragraphs to provide context

questions.rationale: Break complex information into shorter sentences with one idea each. This makes difficult content more accessible.

questions.stem: What is the main purpose of white space in document design?

options.label: To make documents look more professional
To give readers' eyes a rest and improve readability
To fill up empty space on the page
To meet minimum page requirements

questions.rationale: White space gives readers' eyes a rest and makes text more readable by creating visual breaks between sections.

questions.stem: When should you use lists in plain language documents?

options.label: Only for numbered procedures
To break up dense paragraphs and present series of items
Only when you have more than 10 items
Never, they make documents look unprofessional

questions.rationale: Use lists to break up dense paragraphs and present series of items clearly. They make information easier to scan and understand.

questions.stem: How long should paragraphs be in plain language writing?

options.label: 1-2 sentences maximum
3-5 sentences
6-8 sentences
Length doesn't matter as long as content is complete

questions.rationale: Keep paragraphs to 3-5 sentences. Longer paragraphs can overwhelm readers and make text harder to scan.

questions.stem: Match the design element with its plain language purpose:

pairs.right: Tell readers what to expect in each section
Break up dense text and highlight key points
Give readers visual breaks and improve readability

questions.rationale: Each design element serves a specific purpose in making information more accessible to readers.

questions.stem: What makes a document layout truly effective?

options.label: Using many different fonts and colors
Making it look organized and helping readers find information
Filling every available space with text
Using complex formatting to impress readers

questions.rationale: Effective layout looks organized and helps readers find the information they need quickly and easily.

questions.stem: What is the best measure of whether your writing uses plain language effectively?

options.label: It passes all readability tests
Readers can understand and use it successfully
It uses short words and sentences
It follows all the style guidelines

questions.rationale: The best measure is whether readers can actually understand and use your writing successfully - not just whether it follows rules.

questions.stem: Match the testing method with what it reveals:

pairs.right: Whether people can actually complete tasks
Professional assessment of plain language principles
How the document works in real situations

questions.rationale: Different testing methods reveal different aspects of how well your document works for readers.

questions.stem: What should you observe during user testing?

options.label: Only whether users complete tasks correctly
Where users get stuck and how long tasks take
Whether users like the document design
How fast users can read the document

questions.rationale: Watch where users get stuck, how long tasks take, and what causes confusion - this shows you what needs improvement.

questions.stem: A simple way to test your writing is to read it _____ _____.
questions.rationale: Reading your writing out loud helps you catch awkward phrasing, long sentences, and unclear passages.

questions.stem: Why is testing important for plain language writing?

options.label: It's required by government regulations
It ensures your writing actually works for real readers
It helps you meet word count requirements
It makes your writing more professional

questions.rationale: Testing ensures your writing actually works for real readers in real situations - the ultimate goal of plain language.
